channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Queen and Prince Philip are photographed at Windsor Castle to mark the Duke's 99th birthday
item.description: The Queen, 94, and Prince Philip were poignantly photographed side-by-side at Windsor Castle to mark The Duke's 99th birthday on Wednesday.

item.title: Racists or heroes? Black Lives Matter want to topple statues of famous Britons due to slavery links
item.description: Black Lives Matter activists are calling for the removal of 60 statues of slave owners and racists across Britain. On a website called Topple The Racists, members can propose statues to fall.

item.title: Police have ruled out Christian Brueckner as suspect in rape of Irish holiday rep
item.description: Hans Christian Wolters, who is leading the investigation into Christian Brueckner, says the suspect discussed kidnapping, raping and killing a girl in a chat with another paedophile online.

item.title: Vogue editor-in-chief Anna Wintour admits to 'hurtful and intolerant' behavior
item.description: Vogue Editor-in-Chief Dame Anna Wintour has admitted to letting 'hurtful and intolerant behavior' go unchecked during her 32-year reign at the fashion magazine in a memo to staff last week.

item.title: Savvy women gives her tired-looking kitchen a modern makeover for £250
item.description: Lili Pat Dee, from Manchester, took to Facebook group Extreme Couponing and Bargains UK to reveal how she completely revamped her outdated kitchen for just £250.

item.title: Adorable video shows cat waving at the window as his owner arrives home from work
item.description: Sox lives with owner Michael Collins in Halifax, West Yorkshire. The eight-year-old cat has been waving Michael off for the past few years.

item.title: Millions of children might not be able to go back to school in SEPTEMBER
item.description: Gavin Williamson admitted yesterday that the 'ambition' of getting all primary age children back in class for a month before the summer break had been ditched just weeks after it was set.

item.title: Italian woman, 60, prepares stuffed olives while undergoing brain surgery
item.description: Her actions allowed the surgeons to calibrate their work as they operated on the patient's left temporal lobe at the Azienda Ospedali Riuniti in Ancona.

item.title: Billionaire property developer gave Tories £12k two weeks after Robert Jenrick gave plans go ahead
item.description: A billionaire property developer gave a five-figure sum to the Conservative Party a fortnight after the Housing Secretary unlawfully approved one of his schemes.

item.title: Kenneth Noye is seen driving again at exact spot where he killed Stephen Cameron
item.description: Notorious killer Kenneth Noyey, 72, was spotted at the M25 slip-road near Swanley in Kent where he stabbed Stephen Cameron, 21, to death in May 1996.

item.title: Mind blowing video showing how to remove oven glass door in seconds
item.description: An Australian homeowner has revealed how she made her greasy oven door squeaky clean after she discovered a little-known feature that removes the glass in seconds.

item.title: Viewers suggest murdered British backpacker Peter Falconio 'FAKED his own death'
item.description: Channel 4's Murder in the Outback: The Falconio and Lees Mystery looks back at Peter Falconio's disappearance in 2001 while on holiday in Australia with his girlfriend Joanne Lees.

item.title: Mother reveals how a book drew her to quit "mindless shopping" for a minimal lifestyle
item.description: Cassie Tomesek, 34, from Dubbo, New South Wales, reveals how a book on simple living convinced her to stop mindlessly shopping in favour of a house without clutter and a zero-waste lifestyle.

item.title: Coronavirus outbreak has worsened mental health, study says
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic has worsened mental health unlike 'anything seen in recent years', especially for young women, a new study reports.

item.title: Alison Hammond announces her biological father Clifford has died
item.description: Alison Hammond has revealed her biological father Clifford Hammond has passed away in Jamaica.

item.title: Three more Russian Covid-19 patients fall to deaths from hospital windows
item.description: The three further deaths come amid growing concerns among victims' family members that antibiotic drugs used to treat coronavirus patients are causing suicidal thoughts.

item.title: Now 130 Labour councils draw up hit-list of statues with colonial ties
item.description: Dozens of memorials honouring colonial figures have been targeted for removal by activists, who yesterday crossed another name off their nationwide hit-list in London.

item.title: Rapper Wretch32 releases footage of police TASERING his dad
item.description: The clip, released by rapper Wretch 32 on social media tonight, shows officers entering a house, in Tottenham, North London, on April 21 this year at 7.40pm.

item.title: School children under 15 have just a 3.5MILLION-to-one chance of dying from coronavirus
item.description: Analysis of data from the Office for National Statistics by scientists from the University of Cambridge shows that the coronavirus risk to children is extremely low.

item.title: British woman, 89, is killed by gas explosion at her Costa del Sol apartment
item.description: Firefighters who scrambled to the scene discovered the woman's body crushed under rubble. Her husband was also injured in the blast early at the Torre del Mar apartment, east of Malaga.

item.title: London's oldest Elizabethan playhouse known as 'the Red Lion' is unearthed
item.description: Archaeologists believe they have discovered the location of the Red Lion in Whitechapel, east London. It was built around 1567 and was a prototype for the theatre that staged Shakespeare's first plays.

item.title: Mother reveals dodgy £180 fillers made her mouth 'fill with blisters' and lips EXPLODE five times
item.description: Gemma Palmer, 35, from Lancashire, paid £180 to have lip filler in 2018. The filler gathered on one side of her mouth and, despite having the filler dissolved, she has been left in agony ever since.

item.title: Swedish police say they've SOLVED the 1986 murder of PM Olof Palme
item.description: Stig Engström, a designer known as 'Skandia Man' after the company where he worked, has been named by police as the man they believe killed Swedish Prime Minister Olof Palme in 1986.

item.title: Hilarious moment girl attempts to rescue squirrel from kid's paddling pool
item.description: The squirrel is taking a swim around a blue inflatable pool in the backyard of a home in Lumberton, Texas, on June 7, when it is caught on camera.

item.title: Peers will be paid £162 to stay at home and vote on laws without coming to Parliament
item.description: While MPs have been forced to come back to the House of Commons to vote, the upper house has set up an online voting system to allow members to 'vote on a smartphone, laptop or other device.'

item.title: Prince William and Kate Middleton will 'take a leaf from Diana during AIDS epidemic' post-lockdown
item.description: Royal expert Nigel Cawthorne told FEMAIL he thinks the Cambridges will 'take a leaf from Prince William and Harry's mother during the AIDS epidemic' in their approach to returning to public duties.

item.title: ASK TONY: After my wife died, HSBC let me down at every turn
item.description: My wife and I used HSBC to invest our £630,000 retirement savings. After she passed away I was told I'd need a grant of probate. I was surprised as almost everything was in joint names.

item.title: Coronavirus: Social distancing starves people of physical touch
item.description: Loneliness and lack of physical connection has been linked to a multitude of health issues including heart disease and high blood pressure as well as raising levels of stress hormones.

item.title: Fears of violence as far-Right thugs outline plans to 'defend' statues in London this weekend
item.description: Police fear far-Right thugs could descend on the capital this weekend to take on anti-racism protesters. Football hooligans are planning counter-protests to 'defend' memorials.

item.title: Police chief constable 'took the knee' at a Black Lives Matter event
item.description: Alan Pughsley of Kent Police and other officers joined the socially distanced group of more than 50 people in Gravesens last Thursday after George Floyd died in Minneapolis on May 25.

item.title: Athletes who 'take a knee' face BANS at next year's Olympics
item.description: Athletes who breach the rule are subject to discipline on a case-by-case basis and the IOC issued guidelines clarifying that banned protests include taking a knee and other gestures.

item.title: McDonald's makes up the greatest proportion of England's litter by brand
item.description: McDonald's packaging accounts for half of England's fast-food litter, while Coca-Cola makes up one in five discarded non-alcoholic drink containers, a new study reveals.

item.title: Riots could break out in UK this summer, government adviser warns
item.description: Professor Clifford Stott - a member of Number 10's SAGE panel - said urgent efforts are needed by police forces to quell any potential unrest in the neighbourhoods they serve.

item.title: Kensington Palace gardener reveals 75 per cent of his team has been furloughed
item.description: Kensington Palace's head gardener has revealed his fighting spirit, as he leads a scaled-back team to keep the Palace's famous gardens in order amid the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Property market bounces back with 137% sales surge
item.description: The average asking price of sales agreed over the past week was 6 per cent higher than the same week in June 2019 amid pent-up demand in Britain, according to Zoopla.

item.title: More than 500 jobs set to be lost after Monsoon Accessorize entered administration
item.description: British retailer Monsoon Accessorize expects to make 545 staff redundant as it closes 35 stores, and fashion chain Quiz is placing the division that runs its 82 standalone stores into administration.

item.title: Kids do the funniest things! Parents share their children hilarious attempts to be logical
item.description: Social media users from around the world have been sharing their children's most ridiculous and illogical acts in a hilarious online gallery collated by BoredPanda.

item.title: Tracey Cox reveals what it's like to be in a sexless relationship
item.description: Tracey Cox spoke to people in sexless relationships to find out what it's like - inlcuding one British woman, 29, who's devastated, while another wife, 39, says she's perfectly happy.

item.title: Don't be fooled by the Covid cons: We expose Test and Trace scam
item.description: Today we can expose how a shocking security flaw at the heart of the Government's flagship test and trace programme puts us at even greater risk of fraud.

item.title: The sex positions that burn the most and least calories
item.description: The best sex positions for burning calories have been revealed in eye-opening research, following the news that sex in households other than your own has been forbidden in the UK.

item.title: Rishi Sunak 'believes school closures as damaging as credit crunch'
item.description: Chancellor Rishi Sunak is believed to be among the most hawkish in government on the need to reopen schools.

item.title: How you CAN get a holiday refund: Travel firms are clinging onto cash
item.description: Airlines are under investigation for sitting on more than £7bn owed to passengers for cancelled trips, while travel agents have been accused of flouting the law.

item.title: New powers to crack down on cycle lane misuse by motorists
item.description: Drivers will face fines of up to £130 after the Department of Transport announced tougher measures against misuse of cycle lanes in a new law that will be rolled out later this month.
item.media:description: Local authorities will be given new powers to crack down on misuse of cycle lanes (Chris Radburn/PA)

item.title: Mum shares VERY easy recipe for Malteser cake
item.description: Laura Middleton, from Kingston upon Hull, shared her recipe for a Malteser's cake on Facebook group Extreme Couponing and Bargains UK - and it has gone down a storm online.

item.title: Boy is shot dead at his birthday party by 'drunk' gatecrasher
item.description: The child's mother, Vanessa, 30, said the suspect, who appeared to be drunk, was not an invited guest but had arrived with a friend at the celebrations held in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Can you name the film that the iconic garden starred in?
item.description: The illustrations, created by British firm Hayes Garden World, show gardens, parks and landscapes that play a central role in major movie hits - but the characters have been removed.

item.title: Former co-worker tells how George Floyd and Derek Chauvin 'bumped heads' while working at nightclub
item.description: David Pinney (left), who worked with George Floyd and Derek Chauvin at a nightclub in Minneapolis said the two men 'bumped heads', which had a lot to do with the cop being 'extremely aggressive'.

item.title: Dr Fauci calls coronavirus his 'worst nightmare' and says pandemic is far from over
item.description: The bleak admission from Dr. Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, comes as states across the US continue with their gradual reopening efforts.

item.title: Online GP app Babylon Health suffers data breach allowing users to see other patients' consultations
item.description: Rory Glover, who lives in Leeds, wanted to check a prescription on Tuesday morning and found around 50 videos in the Babylon Health app that were not his.

item.title: Horrific video shows four NYPD officers pounce and beat on a cyclist who was doing a solidarity ride
item.description: Pierce McCaffrey had been participating in a solidarity ride during protests along Manhattan's Nassau Street near Gold Street on Sunday at around 7.40pm.

item.title: New IVF research suggests women's eggs 'choose' to attract the sperm of some men but not others
item.description: Women can spend ages finding the perfect man before starting a family. Yet when it comes to biology, Mr Right could actually be wrong. New research has cast new light on compatibility.

item.title: Statue of Christopher Columbus is toppled and thrown in a lake in Richmond
item.description: The sculpture was brought down less than two hours after protesters in Virginia's capital gathered in the city's Byrd Park and chanted for the statue to go.

item.title: Maddie suspect said he had a 'horrible job to do ' the night before the toddler vanished
item.description: A friend of a Christian Brueckner's ex has claimed he told an ex-girlfriend he had a 'horrible job to do in Praia da Luz,' the night before Madeleine McCann went missing in May 2007.

item.title: Frankie and Benny's owner will permanently close 125 restaurants
item.description: The Restaurant Group, which owns Frankie and Benny's, has confirmed plans to close 125 of its sites as it tries to push down rents after the huge hit to the hospitality sector from coronavirus.

item.title: Horror as car being chased by police in West Yorkshire smashes into and kills pedestrian in his 20s
item.description: The motorist crashed into the pedestrian and his Peugeot 307 overturned after he was chased by police through Wakefield in West Yorkshire yesterday afternoon.

item.title: SARAH VINE: I fear for Britain's future if we erase the past (good and bad)
item.description: SARAH VINE: Well, I don't know about you, but events over the past few days have left me feeling very depressed.

item.title: Looters break into Macy's Herald Square and make off with $10,000 worth of merchandise
item.description: More than a dozen looters were captured on surveillance footage stealing about $10,000 in merchandise from Macy's Herald Square store in New York City.

item.title: Beware quick house sale firms that can lead to a hefty loss
item.description: Experts say they have seen a surge in misleading advertising from agents who promise to sell properties within weeks.

item.title: Zoos and drive-in cinemas to be reopened Boris Johnson to announce
item.description: Under pressure from zoos and safari parks that face 'possible extinction', Boris Johnson is expected to announce the outdoor attractions in England can reopen from Monday in tomorrow's briefing.

item.title: More than HALF of residents' in province worst-hit by coronavirus have antibodies
item.description: The city of Bergamo, in Italy, was hit hard by the pandemic that was first detected in February and prompted a strict country-wide lockdown.

item.title: Unemployment could taken SEVEN YEARS to fall back to pre-coronavirus levels according to experts
item.description: Leading economists told the Treasury Committee they predict 'really high unemployment for the foreseeable future' as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Boozy blowouts to Mary Berry...here are 99 things you need to learn about birthday boy Prince Philip
item.description: With coronavirus pandemic ruining plans for a family party, Prince Philip will celebrate his 99th birthday today with a modest lunch with the Queen at Windsor where they have been isolating.

item.title: Only one in FOUR pupils who were allowed to return to school last week showed up for classes
item.description: Government figures have revealed just over half of primary schools in England welcomed back nursery, Reception, Year 1 and 6 pupils in addition to the children of key workers last week.

item.title: IBM ending facial recognition technology amid concern over mass surveillance and racial profiling
item.description: Arvind Krishna, the new CEO of IBM, wrote a letter to Democrat lawmakers on Monday, who are working to reform policing. Krishna said his company would no longer develop facial recognition.

item.title: Mother jailed for two years after son, 9, mauled to death by dog
item.description: Truro Crown Court heard the boy had been left alone at a caravan in the Tencreek Holiday Park in Looe, Cornwall, with the dog named Winston, who had previously bitten another child.

item.title: White men with All Lives Matter sign taunt protesters by reenacting George Floyd's death
item.description: The incident, which resulted in the suspension of a corrections officer and the firing of a FedEx employee who participated, occurred on Monday in Franklinville, New Jersey.

item.title: CrossFit CEO Greg Glassman RESIGNS after he was caught saying we're not mourning for George Floyd
item.description: 'I'm stepping down as CEO of CrossFit, Inc., and I have decided to retire,' Glassman said in a statement on Tuesday, after his remarks and mocking tweet about Floyd drew backlash.

item.title: BBC use photo of the WRONG George Floyd to illustrate the funeral of the man killed by police
item.description: The BBC aired a picture of the former NFL player for the New York Jets George Floyd (right) while presenting a feature on the funeral of the man who was killed by American police in Minneapolis (left).

item.title: DAVID BLUNKETT: The failure to get all children back to school is a betrayal of young lives
item.description: DAVID BLUNKETT: The failure to get all children back to school is a betrayal of young lives. There HAS to be a solution, implored Labour's former Education Secretary, and ex-teacher.

item.title: Human remains found at home of Lori Vallow's husband Chad Daybell as he is taken into custody
item.description: Rexburg Police confirmed human remains were found on Chad Daybell's property in Salem, Idaho, Tuesday. Chad was taken into custody on destruction or concealment of evidence charges.

item.title: HBO Max temporarily pulls Gone With The Wind after accusations it 'glorifies the antebellum south'
item.description: Gone With The Wind has been removed temporarily by HBO Max from its streaming service in the light of widespread unease at America's racial legacy. The film will return 'with historical context'.

item.title: Iran says it will execute 'CIA spy' who 'helped US kill General Soleimani'
item.description: Iran says Seyed Mahmoud Mousavi Majd - an Iranian national accused of spying for the US - accepted a large amount of money to reveal the location of General Soleimani before he was killed by a drone.

item.title: Birdwatcher who filmed Amy Cooper says the incident 'pulled the pin on the race grenade'
item.description: Christian said his decision to start filming Amy Cooper had 'nothing to do with race', but what transpired would fuel a national conversation about the centuries-long history of US racial bias.

item.title: George Floyd will be buried today in Houston next to his mother
item.description: George Floyd, the black man whose brutal death at the hands of police has sparked a worldwide reckoning over racial injustice, will be laid to rest in his hometown of Houston today.

item.title: Stassi Schroeder was shocked by her firing from Vanderpump Rules for her racist actions
item.description: Despite multiple racist comments and an incident in which she falsely called the police on a black co-worker, Stassie Schroeder was reportedly surprised to be fired from Vanderpump Rules.

item.title: Keanu Reeves is back in Bill & Ted Face the Music trailer
item.description: In the trailer, Ted (Keanu Reeves) and Bill (Alex Winter) travel to the future, in which they meet their musclebound and tattooed future selves.

item.title: Have you been microwaving your popcorn wrong?
item.description: If you place a bag of popcorn into the microwave before 'preheating' the microwave itself then you're not getting the best results from your corn kernels.

item.title: Simone Anderson, 29, shows off her incredible body after losing 92 kilograms
item.description: Simone Anderson, from Auckland, New Zealand, has shown off her body transformation after losing a staggering 92 kilos, and revealed how she had to 're-invent' her eating habits in order to get healthy.

item.title: Father of murdered teenager Stephen Lawrence says UK policing is still 'institutionally racist'
item.description: Neville Lawrence (pictured), 78, whose son was stabbed to death in a racist attack in 1993, also praised the tearing down of statues such as that of slave trader Edward Colston in Bristol.

item.title: PAUL THOMAS on... Prince Andrew's legal woes
item.description: 'We're waiting for news on the pub reopening - they're here to interview Prince Andrew'

item.title: Professor suspended after refusing request for lenient marking of black students' assessments
item.description: Gordon Klein, a professor of accounting at the UCLA's Anderson School of Business, rejected a request from a group of non-black students for leniency for their black peers.

item.title: Domestic abuse victims could get paid leave
item.description: The proposed regulations would give victims time to seek professional help, attend police or court appointments, move house and support their children.

item.title: People with O-type blood nearly 20% less likely to test positive for coronavirus, study suggests
item.description: Preliminary data from a new 23andMe study found that people with type O blood were between 9% and 18% less likely than those with other blood types to test positive for coronavirus.

item.title: Kate Garraway seen in London after sharing fears over husband
item.description: The presenter appeared in high spirits following her emotional interview on GMB last Friday where she discussed fears her coronavirus-stricken husband could be comatose 'forever.'

item.title: Sports dietitian Leanne Ward shares the foods that make fat loss easier
item.description: A sports dietitian based in Brisbane has shared the foods that make fat loss easier, and revealed why you can still enjoy some of your favourite foods like milky coffees and popcorn and lose weight.

item.title: Modern-day 'Robinson Crusoes' put desert island up for sale
item.description: Jim Alston and Kim Nguyen tell Ben Fogle on New Lives in the Wild, airing tonight on Channel 5, that they are putting Wilderness Island on the market because it's become a money pit.

item.title: One of the world's most rarely seen whales is found washed up on the Scottish coast
item.description: One of the world's most rarely seen whales has been found washed up on the UK coast for the first time on record.

item.title: Rhodes stays up despite Oxford protest
item.description: A vocal but unsuccessful five-year movement for his removal - calling itself 'Rhodes Must Fall' - has now found itself reborn and firing on rocket fuel after the death of George Floyd.

item.title: 'My mucky mansion HELL!' Katie Price takes fans on a guided tour of her £2m property
item.description: Katie Price took to YouTube on Tuesday to walk her subscribers around her infamous 'mucky mansion' - and revealed that she's selling it.

item.title: Tesla supplier's battery lasts 16 years and a MILLION miles
item.description: Contemporary Amperex Technology, which builds Tesla's batteries, revealed it is ready to produce a rechargeable battery that lasts for 16 years or 1.24 million miles before it would need to be replaced.

item.title: British universities fall in rankings
item.description: Experts blamed 'consistent decreases' in teaching capacity and the impact of the universities' research'.Oxford continues to be the top rated British institution but has fallen from fourth to fifth place.

item.title: 10million patients could be stuck on NHS surgery waiting lists by Christmas due to coronavirus
item.description: The NHS predicts at least 10million people in England and Wales will be on waiting lists for routine surgery if there is a second wave of coronavirus this year.

item.title: French singer jokes he chose girlfriend 'during the ultrasound'
item.description: Speaking on French television, Jean Luc Lahaye, 67, introduced his girlfriend Paula Winckler - believed to be in her 20s - and made light of the age gap, saying men 'always want' younger women.

item.title: George Floyd funeral: Jamie Foxx and Channing Tatum attend
item.description: Jamie Foxx, Channing Tatum and NFL stars attended George Floyd's funeral in Houston, Texas on Tuesday, with Joe Biden making an appearance via video link and Ne-Yo singing.

item.title: Twitter to bring back its 'blue checkmark' verification for individual users after three-year hiatus
item.description: Jane Manchun Wong says that Twitter is working on a new verification system as evidenced by a 'request verification' field found in the 'personal information' section of its app's settings.

item.title: Christian Brueckner has been linked to the murder of a German schoolgirl
item.description: Peggy Knobloch was nine when she vanished on her way home from school in 2001. Part of her skeleton was discovered 15 years later in a Bavarian forest, around 60 miles from her home in Lichtenberg.

item.title: Coronavirus: Asymptomatic people ARE spreading disease
item.description: Harvard's Global Health institute says the WHO 'created confusion' with its statement on Monday during a news briefing that those without symptoms are readily spreading the virus.

item.title: Coronavirus: EU accuses China and Russia of misinformation push
item.description: A 17-page EU report into Chinese and Russian coronavirus misinformation campaigns says Beijing and Moscow had set out to polarise debate and burnish their own images.

item.title: Computer programmer builds COVID-19 face mask with an array of LED lights that move like a mouth
item.description: Game designer and programmer Tyler Glaiel has created a clever new twist on the face mask for people frustrated by trying to communicate with their mouths covered during the COVID-19 pandemic.

item.title: Teen with Tourette's shares eye-opening video of her struggles
item.description: Sophie Adams, 16, has been using social media to try and spread awareness for Tourette's, which involves repetitive movements or unwanted sounds known as tics.

item.title: Plastic surgeon sets up a DRIVE-THRU service for Botox injections in Florida
item.description: Dr. Michael Salzhauer set the quickie clinic up outside his Miami Beach office. Patients fill out paperwork online and drive up to a pull-in garage.

item.title: NHS chief tells staff health service is 'part of problem' in letter on Black Lives Matter protests
item.description: NHS chief executive Simon Stevens said the Black Lives Matter protests and the coronavirus pandemic 'are not disconnected', in a letter shared with NHS England staff yesterday.

item.title: Prince Andrew hands over £355k of his own money to sort out pay breach by his charity
item.description: The Prince Andrew Charitable Trust paid hundreds of thousands to the duke's former private secretary Amanda Thirsk, who stepped down after his disastrous Newsnight interview last year.

item.title: Despairing divorcee, 58, has auditioned countless suitors... with comically disastrous results
item.description: Earlier this year, Kim Thompson made the decision to give up on love and romance, scarred by two years of trying to find a man online with whom she might actually want to form a long-term relationship.

item.title: 'Bewildered' Prince Andrew's standoff with US lawmen
item.description: Prince Andrew was said to be 'utterly bewildered' after he was again accused of refusing to be interviewed by U.S prosecutors investigating Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Alok Sharma says shops to reopen on 15 June
item.description: The move will provide a lifeline for businesses and workers who have taken a battering from the effects of coronavirus and provide a relief for weary consumers who have been stuck at home for months.

item.title: When will Duke and Duchess of Cambridge resume public duties?
item.description: Despite plans for a further easing of lockdown in the UK next week, FEMAIL understands there is currently no set plan in place for the British royal family to step out publicly any time soon.

item.title: Donald Trump slams man, 75, who was pushed to ground by police
item.description: President Donald Trump tweeted out a conspiracy theory Tuesday about the man who was knocked down by Buffalo police at a protester, claiming the man could be an 'ANTIFA porvocateur.'

item.title: Founder of fashion brand Reformation apologizes after a former employee accused the brand of racism
item.description: Former employee Leslieann Elle Santiago shared her difficult experience working for the brand and called out racist behavior. Later, founder Yael Aflalo issues a public apology.

item.title: The striking winning images from the 2020 Sony World Photography Awards
item.description: This year, the competition received 346,000 entries from photographers all around the world in 10 categories including architecture, environment and landscape.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Continued DROP in driving and walking
item.description: Springboard footfall data showed an 11 per cent fall in people going out to shop yesterday compared to the previous week, with numbers also down for every day back to and including June 3.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Anti-coronavirus shield made for plane seats
item.description: A UK-based aircraft interior company has designed what it claims is an 'industry-first' anti-coronavirus personal protection window that can shield passengers from droplet transmission.

item.title: Robber who tried to mug Arsenal players has sentence reduced
item.description: Ashley Smith was sentenced to ten years in November for his involvement in trying to mug Sead Kolasinac and Mesut Ozil in Hampstead, north-west London last year.

item.title: Planets with DUSTY atmospheres are more likely to harbour alien life
item.description: This discovery by researchers from the University of Exeter dramatically extends the number of planets able to host life - and expands the possible habitable zone.

item.title: Hilarious video shows ice-cream-eating cat with 'brain freeze'
item.description: This is the hilarious moment a cat gets its first taste of ice cream and instantly regrets it. The video, posted by a Canadian TikTok user on June 3, shows the cat being fed the frozen treat.

item.title: Yorkshire Tea hits back at far-right YouTuber over anti-Black Lives Matter tweet
item.description: Laura Towler, described as an influential far-right vlogger, received a stern response from the British tea brand after she told them she was 'chuffed' they hadn't posted on Black Lives Matter.

item.title: Study does NOT recommend probiotics for Crohn's disease
item.description: New guidelines released by the American Gastroenterological Association identified only three clinical scenarios where probiotic use might benefit patients.

item.title: Missguided uses size 8 model to advertise plus-size range
item.description: Eagle-eyed shoppers spotted a disclaimer on the UK fast-fashion website Missguided, admitting that the models used for the brand's plus-size collection are from its 'Mainline' range.

item.title: Chinese firefighter saves girl, 5, from balcony at 130 feet
item.description: The five-year-old Chinese child was standing on a tiny ledge and clinging onto the window frame of her 13th floor home when firefighters arrived at the scene in the Chinese city of Kunming today.

item.title: Little Britain removed from Netflix, BBC iPlayer and BritBox
item.description: Little Britain has been removed from Netflix, BBC iPlayer and BritBox amid concerns that the use of blackface characters on the series is no longer acceptable.

item.title: Princess Alice tried to save Russian princesses from murder
item.description: Prince Philip's cousin revealed Princess Alice tried to save Princesses Olga, Maria,Tatiana and Anastasia Nikolaevna before they were murdered during the Russian revolution.

item.title: Coronavirus Iran: 15m may have been infected, official admits
item.description: Fifteen million Iranians may have been infected with coronavirus since Iran's outbreak started in February, one of the country's top health officials admitted today.

item.title: Critics slam 'sexist' government policy closing public toilets
item.description: Speaking to FEMAIL, British charity campaigners and medical experts warned the measure 'adversely and disproportionately affects women and girls'.

item.title: Mysterious repetitive radio bursts reported from deep space
item.description: Researchers from the University of Manchester studied long-term monitoring data from the Lovell Telescope at Jodrell Bank to understand these unusual signals.

item.title: Sweden's coronavirus plan has 'failed miserably', opposition politicians declare
item.description: Jimmie Akesson, leader of the far-right Sweden Democrats, has called for state epidemiologist Anders Tegnell (pictured) to resign, saying his coronavirus strategy has been a 'miserable failure'.

item.title: The interactive IATA coronavirus travel regulations map that reveals restrictions country-by-country
item.description: Simply click on a country and a panel pops up that reveals the latest regulations that apply there. Each country is colour-coded according to how strict its regulations are.

item.title: Urgent recall: Apollo Bay Distiller brewer sells bottles of gin filled with HAND SANITISER
item.description: Apollo Bay Distiller is recalling 700ml bottles of SS Casion Dry Gin, which were sold at the Great Ocean Road Brewhouse in regional Victoria between 5pm on Friday and 7.30pm on Sunday.
